data.title: Jack O’Brien’s ‘Jack Be Nimble,’ and More
data.meta_description: New books by Jack O’Brien, Greg Merritt, Lynda Obst and Billy Crystal.
data.text:
JACK BE NIMBLE

The Accidental Education of an Unintentional Director

By Jack O’Brien

Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $35.

You might not know it from his memoir, but O’Brien is a major player in New York theater. His three best-director Tony Awards (for “Hairspray,” “Henry IV” and “The Coast of Utopia”) prove his versatility too. But most of this gracefully written book is about his early days, and the influence of the temperamental actor-­director Ellis Rabb and the preternaturally talented actress Rosemary Harris, who was Rabb’s wife in the 1960s. Some scenes are quite personal, even invasive, but O’Brien’s admiration for both comes through.

Born in Saginaw, Mich., he entered the University of Michigan, whose campus “roared with unimaginable sophistication,” in 1957. Coastal snobs may smile, but it was in Ann Arbor that O’Brien, now 74, conceived his dream (to become a lyricist) and met the people who led him to his true theatrical calling.

He got in on the ground floor of the Association of Producing Artists, which became the A.P.A.-Phoenix Repertory Company and burst like a supernova on Broadway in the ’60s. O’Brien reminds us that working in American theater then, you could easily cross paths with the likes of Helen Hayes and Eva Le Gallienne.

Even if the author focuses on his mentors, rather than his own success, readers will still wonder how he has achieved what he has. (O’Brien’s big break was directing the bicentennial “Porgy and Bess” in 1976.) For years at A.P.A.-­Phoenix, he writes, he had “little else to do but hold on with both hands, listen, watch and absorb as much as I could.” Maybe that’s the way it works.
